Given the widespread neural involvement and combined volitional and reflexive control, many neurologic conditions can result in swallowing disorders (dysphagia). There is no classification framework for neurogenic dysphagia according to where dysfunction lies within the sensorimotor hierarchy. Thus, underlying neuropathology is not thoroughly considered during dysphagia assessment and rehabilitation. In this review, we explore neurogenic dysphagia through classical sensorimotor hierarchy and movement disorders terminology. We provide comprehensive evidence of dysphagia signs and symptoms in pure cases of movement disorders and discuss nuances related to assessing signs of neuropathology responsible for disordered oropharyngeal swallowing biomechanics. Appreciation of the complexities of dysphagia and investigations into underlying pathologies will advance clinical management of neurogenic dysphagia and inform investigations of dysphagia identification and treatment. Furthermore, the majority of our active rehabilitation approaches have focused on increasing force generation of the muscles involved in swallowing, with an aim to consequently decrease anatomical obstruction to the bolus and/or increase pharyngeal pressure, resulting in improved bolus flow and airway closure. For example, the rationale for use of swallowing strengthening exercises might be something like: (i) during swallowing, floor of mouth muscles activate to lift the hyoid anteriorly and superiorly; (ii) anterosuperior movement of the hyoid is associated with airway protection; (iii) during the act of swallowing with increased voluntary effort, floor of mouth muscles are more active; and thus, (iv) an exercise programme activating the floor of mouth muscles will increase anterosuperior hyoid movement and thus improve airway protection. Unfortunately, the literature on these approaches is not compelling. 16 284-286 This biomechanical approach to intervention has a limited conceptual foundation for how we view oropharyngeal dysphagia. This limitation, in our view, is a fundamental shortcoming in that biomechanical assessment of visualized movement cannot define the underlying neurological nature of the problem. As we expand our understanding of sensorimotor control of swallowing and neuromechanical pathologies underlying deficits associated with neurogenic dysphagia, opportunities for more specific, efficient and efficacious management and rehabilitation approaches will follow. The approach of addressing the deficit is not at issue, but we need to address the neuromechanical deficit instead of the biomechanical deficit. Discussion In this review, we have shown that intact functioning of the muscle, neuromuscular junction, lower motor neurons, upper motor neurons, basal ganglia, cerebellum and sensory systems is necessary for functional oropharyngeal swallowing. That is, a condition that only impacts one of these systems is sufficient to cause dysphagia. We do not currently have a good understanding of the causal relationship between deficits in these sensorimotor systems and resulting changes to swallowing biomechanics, bolus flow and dysphagia sequelae. Without such understanding, the potential for phenotyping and application of well-rationalized treatments for neurogenic dysphagia is limited. Difficulty in developing a phenotypic categorization of dysphagia may stem from inherent limitations in swallowing assessments and evaluation protocols. With the exception of 3D computed tomography, 287 Dysphagia rehabilitation is consequently unspecific due to shortcomings in dysphagia assessment. Current rehabilitation paradigms work on addressing perceived failures in swallowing biomechanics. However, a large proportion of rehabilitations were built on the rationale that reduced oropharyngeal movements are a consequence of weakness and thus focus on strengthening underlying muscle groups. 288 289 15 It is important to acknowledge limitations inherent to a narrative review such as this. While this review aimed to synthesize and interpret a wide range of evidence, the lack of a standardized approach may have resulted in an incomplete representation of the literature base. Nevertheless, we identified a large gap in understanding and present a framework that can be used to drive future hypotheses-driven work. These assessment challenges and lack of strong rehabilitation efficacy data reviewed here allow for exploration of several clinical questions. Tools to quantify oral, laryngeal and pharyngeal sensorimotor functioning such as disruptions in muscle tone can help to gain more specificity in swallowing assessments. Work is needed not only to describe signs and symptoms that are common to a particular dysphagia aetiology but also to investigate the underlying pathophysiologic mechanisms and whether they respond to therapies targeted to address physiology (e.g. neural signalling), biomechanics (e.g. oral and pharyngeal movements and pressure gradients), bolus flow (e.g. airway invasion, residue) and outcomes (e.g. malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, quality of life). While unanswered questions may be frustrating to clinicians, patients and care partners, the potential for improvements to health and quality of life outcomes remain a strong driver in pursuing this difficult work.
